name: Modern Biology
long_desc: This is an introductory course that provides the basis for further studies in biochemistry, cell biology, genetics and molecular biology.  This course emphasizes the chemical principles underlying biological processes and cell structures as well as the analysis of genetics and heredity from a molecular perspective. This is the introductory biology course for all science and nonscience majors.

custom_fields.goals: 1 Apply knowledge of molecular and cellular processes to solve questions about biological systems in normal function and disease states. 2 Explain the significance of individual molecules and cellular pathways in relationship to the following cell survival, cell division, cell growth, tissue growth, and organismal development. 3 Identify several fundamental historical and contemporary questions that biologists seek to answer and explain their importance. 4 Describe the experimental strategies that biologists use to study the natural world.
custom_fields.key_topics: The course will cover: (1) the molecular basis of life including DNA, RNA, and protein structure and function, (2) the connection between the above concepts and ideas from chemistry and physics, (3) Genetic inheritance and the relationship to the ideas above and to diseases, (4) How to interpret biological experiments, (5) Animal function including communication between cells & development, (6) Basics of evolution
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should know: (1) Pre-calculus, including exponentiation and logarithms; (2) Know that molecules are made of atoms that bond together, although details of how the bonds work and relate to energy will be taught; (3) Know that energy is conserved in the universe and that complex systems need external energy to grow, although how this happens in biological systems will be taught
custom_fields.assessment_structure: 3-4 midterm exams and a cumulative final exam. Frequent homework and quizzes, required in-class activities.
custom_fields.relevance: Students will learn core facts about how biological systems work and prepare for possible future course work
custom_fields.learning_resources: Students will be required to read selected chapters of the assigned course text. Optional resources are available to students, which may include the following: online study materials, lecture slides and notes, videos, and selected papers from the literature.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students are expected to spend 3-4 hours per week outside of class working on material (on weeks with exams, that is expected to be 7-9 hours outside of class time).
